awd_titl_txt: A Panel Study of the Dynamics of Change
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project the third wave of a panel survey concerning the community orientation, culture, and engagements of three communities in the midst of social transformations will be collected.  Those surveyed are representative samples from each community, who were interviewed in the first wave in 2011-2013 and re-interviewed in the second wave in 2015-2016.  The series of observations over time will enable assessment of the significance of personal experiences and major events in prompting individuals to change orientations.  The data that this project collects will expand the infrastructure for the diversification of the educational curriculum, benefit other researchers, and are useful for instructional purposes in the classrooms.  The insights provided by this project may inform national security. 


Appropriately modified questions from previous waves will be used for the third survey after testing to ensure they are understood properly.  Respondents from the second wave of the survey, over 2,000 for each community, will be re-interviewed with various measures used to minimize attrition, including use of the same interviewers where possible.  Indices will be constructed in order to examine trends in key concepts.  Fixed effects statistical models will be used to examine causal relationships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
CHANGES IN VALUES: FINDINGS FROM COMPARATIVE PANEL SURVEY IN EGYPT, TUNISIA, AND TURKIYE

Mansoor Moaddel

University of Maryland - College Park

moaddel@umd.edu

A common mistake is to view the upsurge of Islamic fundamentalism and sectarian violence between the rise of the Islamic regime in 1979 Iran and the destruction of the Islamic State in 2017 as an indication that the Middle Eastern publics do not aspire to secular and liberal-democratic values. Three waves of longitudinal surveys carried out in Egypt, Turkiye, and Tunisia in 2011-2013 (wave 1), 2015-2016 (wave 2), and 2020 (wave 3) revealed a pattern of change toward gender equality, secular politics, expressive individualism, and a decline in fundamentalism in Egypt and Turkiye, as well as a partial reversal of these trends in Tunisia. From wave 1 to wave 3, the indices of gender equality (measuring how strongly respondents disagreed with male supremacy in family, education, politics, and job market) increased from 2.1 to 2.26 in Egypt and 2.73 to 3.06 among Turkiye, but remained around 2.5 among Tunisians; secular politics (the extent to which the separation of religion and politics and Western-type government were considered desirable and Islamic government and the sharia undesirable) increased from 2.37 to 2.69 in Egypt and 2.88 to 2.97 in Turkiye but declined in Tunisia from 2.82 to 2.67; and expressive individualism (averaging preference for love versus parental approval in marriage, independence and imagination versus obedience and religiosity as favorable qualities for children, and women's right to dress as they please) rose from 1.87 to 2.09 in Egypt and 2.53 to 2.72 in Turkiye but declined from 2.31 to 2.26 in Tunisia; and liberal values (the average of the three indices) increased from 2.11 in wave 1 to 2.34 in wave 3 in Egypt and 2.70 to 2.91 in Turkiye but decreased from 2.54 to 2.47 in Tunisia. All the indices ranged between 1 and 4.

A significant component of these changes was a sharp increase in support for secular politics and Western-type governance among Egyptians from 44% and 30% in 2007 to 82% and 83%, respectively, in 2020 (Figure 1). As to what triggered this sharp increase, for a sample of respondents, it was their disillusionment with the Muslim Brotherhood, whose candidate was elected as president in 2012 and deposed by the military in 2013. They also maintained that a Western-type government is good for Egypt because it would bring prosperity to their country.

Another remarkable feature in these trends over the course of the survey period was the larger shift toward liberal values among Egyptian women compared to men. These differential changes resulted in a widening gender gap in liberal values (Figure 2).

In Turkiye, on the other hand, the amount of change toward liberal values was much larger for youth bulge (age 18-29) than it was for the older respondents (age 30 and over), particularly in the domain of expressive individualism (Figure 3).

Finally, the index of Islamic fundamentalism, an average response to sixteen questions (which measured orientations toward disciplinarian deity, literalism, religious exclusivity, and religious intolerance) declined from 3.45 to 3.33 among Egyptian and 2.98 to 2.69 among Turkish respondents but remained unchanged at 3.18 among Tunisians. Part of this decline was due to a significant increase in the index of religious tolerance in Egypt and Turkiye from 2.25 and 2.43, respectively, in wave 1, to 2.46 and 2.72 in wave 3. This index declined in Tunisia from 2.73 to 2.45 (Figure 4).
por.por_txt_cntn:
CHANGES IN VALUES: FINDINGS FROM COMPARATIVE PANEL SURVEY IN EGYPT, TUNISIA, AND TURKIYE
Mansoor Moaddel
University of Maryland - College Park
moaddel@umd.edu

A common mistake is to view the upsurge of Islamic fundamentalism and sectarian violence between the rise of the Islamic regime in 1979 Iran and the destruction of the Islamic State in 2017 as an indication that the Middle Eastern publics do not aspire to secular and liberal-democratic values. Three waves of longitudinal surveys carried out in Egypt, Turkiye, and Tunisia in 2011-2013 (wave 1), 2015-2016 (wave 2), and 2020 (wave 3) revealed a pattern of change toward gender equality, secular politics, expressive individualism, and a decline in fundamentalism in Egypt and Turkiye, as well as a partial reversal of these trends in Tunisia. From wave 1 to wave 3, the indices of gender equality (measuring how strongly respondents disagreed with male supremacy in family, education, politics, and job market) increased from 2.1 to 2.26 in Egypt and 2.73 to 3.06 among Turkiye, but remained around 2.5 among Tunisians; secular politics (the extent to which the separation of religion and politics and Western-type government were considered desirable and Islamic government and the sharia undesirable) increased from 2.37 to 2.69 in Egypt and 2.88 to 2.97 in Turkiye but declined in Tunisia from 2.82 to 2.67; and expressive individualism (averaging preference for love versus parental approval in marriage, independence and imagination versus obedience and religiosity as favorable qualities for children, and women's right to dress as they please) rose from 1.87 to 2.09 in Egypt and 2.53 to 2.72 in Turkiye but declined from 2.31 to 2.26 in Tunisia; and liberal values (the average of the three indices) increased from 2.11 in wave 1 to 2.34 in wave 3 in Egypt and 2.70 to 2.91 in Turkiye but decreased from 2.54 to 2.47 in Tunisia. All the indices ranged between 1 and 4.

A significant component of these changes was a sharp increase in support for secular politics and Western-type governance among Egyptians from 44% and 30% in 2007 to 82% and 83%, respectively, in 2020 (Figure 1). As to what triggered this sharp increase, for a sample of respondents, it was their disillusionment with the Muslim Brotherhood, whose candidate was elected as president in 2012 and deposed by the military in 2013. They also maintained that a Western-type government is good for Egypt because it would bring prosperity to their country.



Another remarkable feature in these trends over the course of the survey period was the larger shift toward liberal values among Egyptian women compared to men. These differential changes resulted in a widening gender gap in liberal values (Figure 2).



In Turkiye, on the other hand, the amount of change toward liberal values was much larger for youth bulge (age 18-29) than it was for the older respondents (age 30 and over), particularly in the domain of expressive individualism (Figure 3).



Finally, the index of Islamic fundamentalism, an average response to sixteen questions (which measured orientations toward disciplinarian deity, literalism, religious exclusivity, and religious intolerance) declined from 3.45 to 3.33 among Egyptian and 2.98 to 2.69 among Turkish respondents but remained unchanged at 3.18 among Tunisians. Part of this decline was due to a significant increase in the index of religious tolerance in Egypt and Turkiye from 2.25 and 2.43, respectively, in wave 1, to 2.46 and 2.72 in wave 3. This index declined in Tunisia from 2.73 to 2.45 (Figure 4).



The pattern of trends in values thus varied by country and domain. In Turkiye, there was a steady increase in support for liberal values and decline in fundamentalism during the period of the surveys. In Egypt, the rise in support for the separation of religion and politics and Western-type government was much higher than the other two countries, while the increase for gender equality and expressive individualism was small (even though it was statistically significant). In Tunisia, the decline in liberal values indicated a rise in secular authoritarianism, not fundamentalism. While the Islamic fundamentalist beliefs are supported by a majority across the three countries and male supremacy by a majority of Egyptian and Tunisian respondents, a much lower percentage of respondents supported religious intolerance and a great majority supported gender equality in the domain of education. Therefore, it is reasonable to expect that the increase in religious tolerance is the driver for the decline of fundamentalism and that the expansion of female education is the path of least resistance by the institutions of male domination and would lead to a greater acceptance of gender equality in these countries. These findings are consistent with those from other NSF-funded research in Iraq, Iran, and Saudi Arabia, which have shown similar changes in values, particularly in increasing support for secular politics and declining trust in religious institutions.

					Submitted by: Mansoor Moaddel
